item.title: About
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded: Željko Filipin talks with Watir developers and users about Watir. [gallery link="file" columns="4"]

item.title: #1 Bret Pettichord on Watir
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded: Željko Filipin talks with Bret Pettichord (CTO, WatirCraft LLC; Lead Developer, Watir) about Watir and what it does and doesn't do well. Bret describes how people are building frameworks with Watir and the reasons why Watir was created in the first place. Also included are his thoughts on recorders and open-source and his new company, WatirCraft. Note: When Bret talks about ssh, he is thinking about ssl.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I enjoyed the podcast. I was always interested in how wat-ear started out (cracks me up, the original pronunciation, especially because I've heard that from a bunch of French people). I like faucets, though I'm not married to it. I wouldn't mind if you plugged that a little.
- Dave
Dave, I am glad you liked it. I am not sure what you mean by faucets, could you please explain?
Well done. I look forward to listening to the next installment.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Testing Podcast » Blog Archive » Watir Podcast #1: Bret Pettichord on Watir
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] notes: #1 Bret Pettichord on Watir    watir_podcast_1.mp3 [...]

item.title: Questions
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded:
Alister Scott, Bret Pettichord, Alan Baird, Charley Baker, Jari Bakken and Rich Downie contributed to questions, mostly at #watir IRC channel. If you have a question or six, leave a comment.

Introduction

  • Something about you.
  • Where do you live?
  • How did you get into:
    • computers (your first computer),
    • software testing,
    • automation/Watir/Ruby.
  • Have you used other programming languages?
  • If so how do you think it compares with Ruby?
  • Why do you like testing?
  • What is that you like the most about testing?
  • A little about the application you are testing. (Jari Bakken)
  • How big are development and test teams at your company?
  • Whick editor/IDE are you using for writing Watir/Ruby code?
  • Which OS are you using?

Watir

  • When did you start using Watir? (Bret Pettichord)
  • What have been using Watir for? (Bret Pettichord) Regression, smoke, unit tests... (Alan Baird)
  • What do you like about Watir? (Bret Pettichord)
  • What don't you like about Watir? (Bret Pettichord)
  • What frameworks have you been using with Watir? Test::Unit, RSpec, WET... (Alan Baird)
  • What would you like to see in future versions of Watir?
  • Have you used other flavours of Watir? (Firewatir, Safariwatir, Watij, Watin...)
  • Have you used other testing tools, open or closed source (Selenium...)? (Rich Downie)
  • If so how do you think it compares with Watir? (Rich Downie)
  • Do other people use your Watir code? (Bret Pettichord)
  • Have you built any tools of your own? (Bret Pettichord)
  • How do you help out with Watir? (Bret Pettichord)
  • Any metric you find relevant to share (time to run tests, number of tests or assertions, lines of code, functionality covered...)?

For Watir flavours

  • How would you compare your flavour of Watir with the Ruby one?
  • What is the current status of your project? (Charlie Baker)
  • What is the roadmap? (Charlie Baker)
  • How big is community for your tool?
  • Do you have documentation?
  • How many developers are working on the tool?
  • Do you know how many users/downloads/installations you have?
  • Would you (and how) convince me to switch to your tool?

Closing

  • Would you share with us interesting/funny testing/bug hunt story?
  • What do you like to do beside testing?
  • Do you listen to podcasts?
  • Any closing thoughts? Something you would like to say to listeners?
  • Do you have a web site/twitter account?

item.title: #4 Jeroen van Menen on WatiN
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded: Željko Filipin talks with Jeroen van Menen, WatiN (Web Application Testing In .Net) Lead Developer. Take a look at WatiN Test Recorder created by Daaron Dwyer. Music at the beginning and the end is Bodhgaya from The Nightfall Project, selected by Jeroen van Menen.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi i'm still new for using watin, but i like it. I'm using visual studio 2005, .net framework 2.0 and want to run it in NUnit 2, my project name Dimas2(watin).sln and my config name Dimas2(watin).config. My problem is where i must set the apartmentstate = STA. I already use like have been told in http://watin.sourceforge.net/apartmentstateinfo.html#nunit, and when i run it, still have this message "....System.Threading.ThreadStateException : The CurrentThread needs to have it's ApartmentState set to ApartmentState.STA to be able to automate Internet Explorer."
Maybe, there is something i'm not doing. i hope i could big help from you, please..:-)
Thanks before Irvinia

Hi Irvinia,
You should post your question at watin-users mailing list at https://lists.sourceforge.net/lists/listinfo/watin-users
Željko
Published Watir Podcast 4: Jeroen van Menen, WatiN Lead Developer http://watirpodcast.com/4/

item.title: Contribute
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded: If you would like to talk to me about Watir, let me know. All you need is about minutes, Skype and a microphone. There is a list of questions I usually ask, but do not get over prepared. :) After the podcast is recorded and edited, I will upload it to the site, but I will not publish it. I will send you the link to the file and only after you say it is ok, I will publish it. I can always cut anything you would not like to be published, or delete the podcast and never publish it if that is what you want. I will need your small image of you for the episode page (73×73 px), but that is optional. The name of the company you work for and your job title there are optional too. If you have a band (or know somebody that has a band) and you would like a little promotion, let me know. I can use about 30 seconds of music at the beginning and about 60 seconds at the end of each show. If you have a question or six, if you would like to suggest somebody I should talk to, leave a comment.

item.title: #8 Alister Scott
item.dc:creator: alan.baird
item.content:encoded: Željko Filipin talks with Alister Scott about his experiences in test automation and using Watir to automate tons of tests. Alister also talks about his new position as Watir Wiki Master and how the Watir community can continue to improve this resource. Music at the beginning and the end of the podcast is Bach - Goldberg Variation No. 10 performed by Pistos, a regular at the Watir IRC channel #watir on Freenode.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: [...] Check it out if you’re interested: http://watirpodcast.com/alister-scott/ [...]

item.title: #9 Paul Rogers
item.dc:creator: alan.baird
item.content:encoded: Željko Filipin talks with Paul Rogers, one of the co-creators of Watir, about Watir. Paul currently writes some interesting tests for tynt, a company that makes web editing software.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
As usual the podcast was most informative. I have listened to everyone and learn something new every time.
Please keep up the excellent work.
Carl

Carl, thanks a lot. I do not get a lot of comments, so I appreciate every one so much. I hope to record a lot of podcasts at AWTA 2009. Also, I will buy a better microphone, so the audio quality should improve.
Watir Podcast 9: Paul Rogers http://watirpodcast.com/paul-rogers/

Comments on Watir podcast site are not the best place for this discussion. Could you please post your question to watir-general?

item.content:encoded: Željko Filipin talks with Bret Pettichord (CTO, WatirCraft LLC; Lead Developer, Watir) about WatirCraft, a testing framework that builds on Watir. Thanks to Chuck van der Linden for a lot of questions for this podcast. Music at the beginning and the end of the podcast is the world premiere of G Blues Train Intro by my brother Marko Filipin.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great interview. I'm keen to see more detail about the rasta/roo integration, and also the logging/reporting. Another thing I am interested in finding out about is passing data between tests, to create test scenarios.
And one more thing, might be a bit confusing calling the framework the same name as the company.
Alister, thank you for the kind words. :)
Alpinweis, as far as I know WatirCraft framework is not in active development any more.

got a chance to finish listening to zeljko and sai's interview with angrez singh on firewatir - good stuff http://bit.ly/CkAdY
RT @skim RT @zeljkofilipin: #Watir Podcast #27: Angrez Singh on FireWatir (with @sai_venkat) http://bit.ly/in8Wk
Watir Podcast #27 Angrez Singh on FireWatir (with @sai_venkat) http://bit.ly/in8Wk

Hi Angrez,
Good work !
As you said, watir is a easy tool to learn, and i noticed couple of drawbacks while using the tool.
1. when Popup or window comes up. 2. Can not go for debugging mode( can do in other tools like QTP, Test Complete). 3. No built in functionality to generate the reports.
Great job Angrez!!!

Hi Shiddu,
Don't compare WATIR with commercial tools like QTP, Test Complete,etc.
WATIR is an open source application.

Aidy Lewis (http://twitter.com/aidy_lewis) is from London.
Or ask at http://groups.google.com/group/watir-general. 1700+ Watir users there. There must be somebody from London.

OK - I guess I didn't listen to the whole podcast, must have skipped the last minute (just re-listened to it).
I haven't used WatiR before, but I have used Selenium and WebDriver a lot.
I have started an Agile Testing meetup group in London (http://www.meetup.com/agiletesting). Do you know anyone who would be interested in talking about WatiR at the meetup group, giving a quick demo and explaining the benefits of using WatiR over other tools?
Thanks again..

I counted the number of times Angrez Singh used the word "basically" and "I mean" throughout the podcast. It is 84 times.
Test it out.
Pradeep, try to count how many times I say "actually". Probably even more than 84 times. :)
I did count, it actually comes to about 92
Forgot to say: Good work Zeljko!
Thanks Pradeep, I do my best. And, it is hard to mess up with such good guest and co-host. :)

Hi Željko,
The talk description mentions that Hemal was going to be talking in this episode - but I listened to the whole thing and didn't hear him. What happened?
If you are interested, Hemal is talking at SkillsMatter in London tomorrow (27/10/09) - you can catch the video podcast on their site a few days later.
http://skillsmatter.com/event/agile-testing/how-we-build-quality-software-at-uswitch-com
Thanks..
Nathan Bain
Hi Nathan. Hemal said a few words at the end of the show (starting at 36:59). I guess it is not clear what "featuring" means. :) It is just a way to promote people and companies that use Watir.
[...] can listen to the podcast of my interview with the Watir team on: [...]

item.title: #29 Bret Pettichord and Charley Baker on Past, Present and Future of Watir
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded:
Bret Pettichord (Watir Lead Developer), Charley Baker (Watir Lead Developer) and Željko Filipin (Watir Community Manager) talk about the past, the present and the future of Watir.
  • 0:00 - music
  • 1:00 - introduction
  • 2:11 - Bret on what is new in Watir 1.6.5
  • 2:54 - downloads
    • gemcutter.org/gems/watir
    • gemcutter.org/gems/firewatir
    • gemcutter.org/gems/commonwatir
    • rubyforge.org/frs/?group_id=104
  • 5:15 - in the year since the last release of Watir (1.6.2) more people contributed to 1.6.5 than ever before, thanks to GitHub
  • 7:40 - all Watir drivers now at watir.com
  • 9:29 - Charley on releasing Watir 1.6.5
  • 12:47 - move more gems in Watir, or separate all gems?
  • 17:00 - Watir 2.0
  • 20:50 - WatirSpec, results + todo (793 examples, 59 failures)
  • 22:29 - Celerity
  • 24:16 - FFI extension for Ruby
  • 30:10 - WatiN, Watij
  • 32:31 - Bret: "Watin is in the wrong language."
  • 36:16 - Bret: "Selenium ... does not use any special facilities from any language that it works in, and therefore it is kinda clumsy in most of them."
  • 36:54 - summary of Watir 1.6.5
  • 38:53 - AWTA 2010
  • 39:50 - Watir 1.7 (pop ups, cookies)
  • 46:08 - API changes in Watir 2.0 (hashes, 0-based indexing)
  • 49:18 - early days of Watir
  • 54:15 - closing
  • 55:19 - you can donate to Watir at watir.com
  • 55:37 - our sites
  • 56:48 - music
Music at the beginning and the end of the podcast is Easy to Love by Chris McMahon.

item.title: #32 Brent Strange
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded:
Gregg Yows and Željko Filipin talk with Brent Strange on his blog post Testing in 2009, a Year in Review. We are proud to be a part of Testing Podcast family. You can find audio podcasts on software testing there. All of them. A big thank you to Tiffany Fodor for editing the audio, and to Alan Baird for show notes. Show Notes:
  • 0:28 - News:
    • Watir Podcast is a member of Testing Podcast
    • Jarmo Pertman's blog IT Really Matters added to Watir Blogs page
    • Watir Wiki has been updated, please give us your feedback
    • Jari Bakken just released pre-release of Watir-Webdriver (install instructions at Watir on WebDriver)
    • Donate to Watir!
    • Brent Strange - how strange is that
  • 3:43 - Brent introduction (works for GoDaddy)
  • 4:21 - Strange Beer
  • 5:14 - How Brent Uses Watir
  • 9:02 - Training folks on Watir
  • 11:08 - test navigate and execute
  • 11:52 - Explain this pattern: using Test::Unit, there aren't any assertions in test and navigate
  • 14:53 - What tools do you use? (team foundation server, SciTE, .net windows)
  • 16:16 - Watir v Selenium (or Why Watir?) - cost, support for multiple browsers, community support, ruby easy to learn. Worry about Selenium in a frame (not really an issue).
  • 18:48 - Record and playback helpers - lack of record and playback on ruby, it's not the way to go
  • 20:21 - Selenium community support as good as watir
  • 20:42 - SWEA - established relationship w/ developer
  • 21:16 - what's with you're url? (www.1qainsight:8080) - he's cheap
  • 22:58 - QA Engineer vs Software Tester - is there a difference? (going through the backdoor with agile)
  • 27:00 - The Software Testing Club Magazine - No 1 - Do Loop Until 0 comics
  • 29:00 - Roo/Rasta - just using it for reading spreadsheets, but they are moving away from it
  • 31:38 - What do you do when you aren't at a computer - website dev for charity, gym, hunt (deer and elk), sports, church (Arizona)
  • 33:22 - Favorite Podcasts? - James Bach, church sermons
  • 34:44 - Closing thoughts - keep up the good work
  • 35:46 - qainsight.net
  • 36:00 - twitter? who uses that?
  • 36:28 - Do Loop Until 0, we can forget about that
  • 37:18 - oh yeah...we forgot to introduce ourselves
  • 37:28 - Hi, I'm Greg Yows
  • 38:42 - Hi, I'm Zeljko
  • 40:18 - licensing

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Brent, you are correct, bit.ly and similar links can lead to dangerous places.
Just to make it clear, I am not suggesting that people use bit.ly or similar sites to create nice URLs, just to make sure URLs on their sites are nice.

Željko, your pickiness of URLs could lead smart 'clickers' to not click because of the security and virus danger within!
For example, watch the video here: http://techcrunch.com/2009/09/24/video-symantec-shows-the-danger-of-shortened-twitter-links/
The fact that the short URL obfuscates where the intended clicker is going is not a good thing. So, I've changed my mind, I have a long URL not to be "cheap" but to provide security to my readers! :)
Thanks Steve, that URL looks nice. :)

item.title: #33 Jake Dempsey and Brian Knorr on Watij and UISpec
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded:
Željko Filipin talks with Jake Dempsey and Brian Knorr on Watij. The music in the show is Love Lies by Paper Lions. Chris McMahon played bass in Paper Lions in early Eighties. We are proud to be a part of Testing Podcast family. You can find audio podcasts on software testing there. All of them. A big thank you to Tiffany Fodor for editing the audio and for show notes. Show notes:
  • 0:00 - Welcome and Introductions
  • 1:35 - Watij History

  • 14:15 - Links to our sites.

item.title: #45 Bret Pettichord's Opening Keynote at Selenium Conference 2011
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded: Bret Pettichord's Opening Keynote at Selenium Conference 2011. This is the first time I have published a podcast that I did not record, but this is one of the best talks I have heard so far and I thought it should be published here. I would like to thank Michael Larsen for producing the podcast. Show notes are at Michael Larsen's Podcasts page and Bret's blog post A Ninja Strike to the Brain. Bret's blog post also has video version of the talk.

I shared this out with my team as follows:
Excellent overview of what works in web testing based on 20 years of experience. Hammers on Mercury/HP QTP. ~20m long podcast. Video at [http://watir.com/2011/05/15/a-ninja-strike-to-the-brain/]
FYI (and shows how little I know about this market): Mercury has been purchased and rebranded as HP QTP (Quick Test Professional)

item.title: #46 Jarmo Pertman on Watir 2.0
item.dc:creator: zeljko.filipin
item.content:encoded:
Željko Filipin talks with Jarmo Pertman about the recent release of Watir 2.0. This episode is sponsored by Watir book! If you would like to sponsor an episode, let me know. Music at the beginning and the end of the podcast is by George Sanders from Portland, Oregon. We are proud to be a part of Testing Podcast family. You can find audio podcasts on software testing there. All of them. Show notes:
  • 1:00 – Introduction.
  • 1:38 - Jarmo's gems: RAutomation and WatirSplash.
  • 2:44 - Watir 2.0: zero based indexing, firewatir is deprecated, locators for collections, default zero based locators.
  • 9:48 - Future plans: decrease incompatibilities between watir and watir-webdriver gems even further with the help of watirspec gem.
  • 11:12 - Our sites.
  • 12:15 - Jarmo says a few words in Estonian.
